pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>endocrine system</button> is one of the two main control systems of the human body. Thus, it enables responses to stimuli that are necessary to maintain homeostasis. Several <button class='glossary-text'>endocrine glands</button> secrete <button class='glossary-text'>hormones</button> into the bloodstream. Each hormone exerts its effects by binding to receptors on or within target cells. In this investigation, the student will learn about the major endocrine organs and hormones as well as the effects of hormones on their targets in the body. Students will apply this knowledge to a series of case studies of patients with various endocrine disorders.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation – 45-60 minutes
Activity 1: Case Studies – 15-20 minutes per case study
pageData.desc:
Preparation – 45-60 minutes
Activity 1: Case Studies – 15-20 minutes per case study

text: Explain the role of the <button class='glossary-text'>endocrine system</button> in homeostasis.
Describe what <button class='glossary-text'>hormones</button> are and how both steroid and <button class='glossary-text'>nonsteroid hormones</button> work.
List and describe the major endocrine organs, their hormone secretions, and the effects of those hormones on their targets.
Explain how feedback is essential for homeostasis, and relate specific examples pertaining to the endocrine system.
Analyze case studies of patients with endocrine-related disorders.

pageData.text: Vitamin D is a <button class='glossary-text'>hormone</button> that plays many important roles in the body. Vitamin D regulates calcium and phosphorus levels in the body and aids in the mineralization of bone. Rickets is a disease that is associated with low levels of vitamin D. Prolonged deficiency can result in the softening and weakening of bones in children. Vitamin D deficiency in adults causes osteomalacia, a softening of the bones. Both rickets and osteomalacia are caused because mineralization of bone does not occur correctly. Vitamin D is also important for the immune system, and it has been suggested that since every cell has Vitamin D receptors it may play even more roles in maintaining overall health.

Vitamin D is sometimes called the “the sunshine vitamin” because our bodies can produce it with the help of sunlight. People who have Vitamin D deficiencies often do not spend much time outdoors (either by choice or because of the weather), have darker skin (because melanin acts to block out the sun's rays), or do not consume foods that contain the vitamin. Plants, fungi, and animal products naturally produce forms of Vitamin D that the human body can utilize. In addition to these food sources, there are many other foods (milk, orange juice, cereal, etc.) that are fortified with Vitamin D by manufacturers.

pageData.desc: A woman wearing sunglasses lying on the grass in bright sunshine.
pageData.altText: A woman wearing sunglasses lying on the grass in bright sunshine.

pageData.subTitle: Endocrine System and Hormones
pageData.text: The body is made up of organ systems—a number of organs that operate collectively to carry out certain body functions. Each organ system has specific tasks to perform to maintain life. The interdependent, coordinated activities of organ systems are necessary to maintain homeostasis—the dynamic equilibrium the body sustains when in good health.

The <button class='glossary-text'>endocrine system</button> is one of the two major control systems of the body; the other is the nervous system. The endocrine system is a collection of glands, including the pituitary, thyroid, and <button class='glossary-text'>pancreas</button>. In contrast to the nervous system, which generates rapid, transient responses to stimuli, the endocrine system generates slower, more sustained responses. The two systems communicate with one another and, together, regulate the other organ systems of the body, managing their functions and maintaining homeostasis.

<button class='glossary-text'>Endocrine glands</button> typically secrete directly into the bloodstream, which carries the <button class='glossary-text'>hormones</button> to their targets within the body. This makes endocrine glands different from exocrine glands, such as salivary glands, which secrete through ducts to a specific location, such as the oral cavity. However, as described below, some endocrine glands have exocrine as well as endocrine secretions.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the function of the endocrine system?

options.text: a collection of glands that regulates other organ systems
a network of nerves that perceives and generates responses to stimuli
the hormones that process sensory information
the organs that synthesize new cells for body growth and healing
the organs and tissues that produce chemical signals in the body

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The endocrine gland is a collection of glands, including the pituitary, thyroid, and pancreas. The endocrine system generates slow, sustained signals as it regulates other organ systems and maintains homeostasis.

pageData.question: The endocrine system is one of the two major control systems of the body. What is the other major control system?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The nervous system and endocrine system communicate with each other and the interdependent, coordinated activities of organ systems are necessary to maintain homeostasis.

Endocrine glands typically secrete directly into the bloodstream, which carries the hormones to their targets within the body.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The endocrine system is one of the two major control systems of the body; the other is the nervous system. The endocrine system is a collection of glands, including the pituitary, thyroid, and pancreas. In contrast to the nervous system, which generates rapid, transient responses to stimuli, the endocrine system generates slower, more sustained responses. The two systems communicate with one another and, together, regulate the other organ systems of the body, managing their functions and maintaining homeostasis. Endocrine glands typically secrete directly into the bloodstream, which carries the hormones to their targets within the body.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Hormones</button> are the chemical messengers secreted from <button class='glossary-text'>endocrine glands</button> and transported to receptor-bearing target cells. When a receptor binds its corresponding hormone, this triggers changes in the target cell. There are two categories of hormones:

text: are small lipid molecules synthesized from cholesterol. Because they are lipids, steroid hormones are fat-soluble and pass easily through cell membranes (see Figure 1). Steroid hormones typically have intracellular receptors; in other words, the receptors are located within the cell, in the cytoplasm or nucleus. The hormone binds to the receptor within the cell. It may bind a cytoplasmic receptor and then enter the nucleus, or it may enter the nucleus and bind the receptor there. Either way, once the hormone-receptor complex is in the nucleus, gene expression is altered and protein synthesis is altered within the target cell.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diagram of the mechanism of action of a typical steroid hormone on a target cell

pageData.text:
1. The steroid hormone passes through the cell membrane and encounters a receptor.
  2. The hormone binds the receptor.
  3. The hormone-receptor complex enters the nucleus.
  4. The hormone-receptor complex activates specific genes.
  5. The genes are transcribed into messenger RNA (mRNA).
  6. The mRNA transcript passes into the cytoplasm and associates with a ribosome.
  7. Protein synthesis occurs on the ribosome.

text: are water-soluble proteins, peptides, or amino acids. They are much more prevalent in the than . Their receptors project from the outer surfaces of target cell membranes (see Figure 2). When a nonsteroid hormone, also known as a , binds its cell surface receptor, this results in the formation of an intracellular molecule called a , such as cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP), which is formed from adenosine triphosphate (ATP) by an enzyme. The second messenger may then initiate a variety of changes in the cell, including the activation of a type of enzyme called a protein kinase. A protein kinase affects the function of cellular proteins by adding phosphate groups to them.

pageData.text:
1. The nonsteroid hormone (first messenger) encounters and binds a cell surface receptor.
  2. Hormone-receptor binding activates a specific enzyme.
  3. The enzyme acts on ATP.
  4. The ATP is converted to cAMP, the second messenger.
  5. The second messenger activates a protein kinase.
  6. The protein kinase phosphorylates specific proteins.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Diagram of the mechanism of action of a typical nonsteroid hormone on a target cell

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the difference between nonsteroid and steroid hormones?

options.text: Nonsteroid hormones are water-soluble; steroid hormones are fat-soluble.
Nonsteroid hormones come from cholesterol; steroid hormones come from amino acids.
Nonsteroid hormones are less prevalent than steroid hormones.
Nonsteroid hormones are first messengers; steroid hormones are secondary messengers.
Nonsteroid hormone receptors are in the cell; steroid hormone receptors are on the cell.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Nonsteroid hormones are water-soluble proteins, peptides, or amino acids. Steroid hormones are small lipid molecules synthesized from cholesterol and therefore fat-soluble.

pageData.question: Which of the following is most likely a steroid hormone receptor?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Steroid hormones typically have intracellular receptors in the cytoplasm or nucleus. The hormone binds to the receptor within the cell. It may bind a cytoplasmic receptor and then enter the nucleus, or it may enter the nucleus and bind the receptor there.

pageData.text: The includes several major glands (see Figure 3). However, a number of other organs, such as the stomach and heart, have secondary endocrine functions. The major and their , which are summarized in , are the primary focus of this investigation. Less emphasis is placed on the hormones of the gonads (ovaries and testes), placenta, and . Although these are important endocrine glands, in-depth examination of the gonads and placenta typically occurs in the context of the reproductive system, and the thymus is examined closely as part of the lymphatic and immune system.

Before examining the major endocrine glands and their hormones, it is essential to understand the concept of feedback and its significance for homeostasis. Feedback is not limited to the endocrine system; it occurs in the other organ systems as well. There are two types of feedback:

text: <button class='glossary-text'>Positive feedback</button> involves amplification of the response to a stimulus that is disruptive to homeostasis. The response stops when the stimulus has been eliminated or removed. For example, when a blood vessel is injured, this triggers the blood clotting cascade, a series of chemical reactions that quickly seals off the injured site.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Drawing of the major endocrine glands and their locations in the human body

text: is stabilizing feedback. Several examples in which the secretion of a from an acts on target cells, which in turn signal to the gland to reduce or stop secretion of the hormone, are in the following sections. Negative feedback is much more common in the body than . Unless otherwise indicated, assume that the term feedback in this investigation refers to negative feedback.

pageData.subTitle: Hypothalamus and Pituitary Gland
pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>hypothalamus</button> is a key player in both the <button class='glossary-text'>endocrine system</button> and the nervous system. It functions as the manager of the endocrine system by secreting hormones that target other endocrine glands. The hypothalamus is attached to the <button class='glossary-text'>pituitary gland</button> (see <button class='resource-text'>Figure 3</button>), which also produces a variety of hormones that regulate the function of other endocrine glands. Hormones that regulate the production of other hormones are referred to as <button class='glossary-text'>tropic hormones</button>. The tropic hormones of the hypothalamus are discussed below in the context of the glands they influence.

The pituitary (see Figure 4) is divided into two portions: the <button class='glossary-text'>posterior pituitary</button> and the <button class='glossary-text'>anterior pituitary</button>. You may think of the posterior pituitary as an extension of the <button class='glossary-text'>hypothalamus</button>. It is connected to the hypothalamus by specialized secretory nerve fibers, and its <button class='glossary-text'>hormones</button> are actually produced in the hypothalamus and then stored in the posterior pituitary prior to secretion.

text: (ADH), or vasopressin, is a peptide that promotes the formation of concentrated urine by the kidneys, thereby helping the body conserve water. occurs when the kidneys are unable to concentrate urine due to either an ADH deficiency or the kidneys’ inability to respond to this hormone. The hallmarks of diabetes insipidus are (intense thirst that is not relieved by fluid intake) and (the production of a large volume of dilute urine).

<button class='glossary-text'>Oxytocin</button> is a peptide hormone that effects the release of milk from the mammary glands (the letdown reflex) and also brings about cervical dilation and uterine contractions during labor. Both milk letdown and labor contractions are regulated by <button class='glossary-text'>positive feedback</button>. Letdown is stimulated by the sensation of an infant suckling at the breast. However, for many mothers, the letdown reflex may be triggered simply by hearing their infant cry. Milk release is sustained until the infant is no longer suckling. In childbirth, uterine contractions become stronger and more frequent until the newborn has passed through the birth canal.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: Diagram of the pituitary gland, its hormones, and their target organs

pageData.question: Which of the following amplifies the response to a stimulus that is disruptive to homeostasis?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Positive feedback involves amplification of the response to a stimulus that is disruptive to homeostasis. Negative feedback is stabilizing feedback.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes a hormone involved in a positive feedback loop?

options.text: Oxytocin initiates uterine contractions, which become stronger until the infant is born.
Antidiuretic hormone promotes urine concentration until enough water is conserved.
Growth hormone promotes cell growth in some cell types during childhood.
Luteinizing hormone stimulates sex hormone production until appropriate levels are reached.
Thyrotropin secretion is stimulated or inhibited by certain hypothalamic hormones.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: In childbirth, uterine contractions become stronger and more frequent until the newborn has passed through the birth canal. This is an example of positive feedback.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Feedback loops are extremely important in maintaining hemostasis. Positive feedback involves amplification of the response to a stimulus that is disruptive to homeostasis. The response stops when the stimulus has been eliminated or removed. Negative feedback is stabilizing feedback in which the glandular secretion of a hormone acts on target cells, which in turn signals to the gland to reduce or stop secretion of the hormone.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Feedback loops are extremely important in maintaining hemostasis. Positive feedback involves amplification of the response to a stimulus that is disruptive to homeostasis. The response stops when the stimulus has been eliminated or removed. Negative feedback is stabilizing feedback in which the glandular secretion of a hormone acts on target cells, which in turn signals to the gland to reduce or stop secretion of the hormone.

pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>anterior pituitary</button> differs from the <button class='glossary-text'>posterior pituitary</button> in that it produces its own <button class='glossary-text'>hormones</button>. However, the secretion of anterior pituitary hormones is controlled by releasing and inhibiting hormones from the <button class='glossary-text'>hypothalamus</button>.

text: (GH), or somatotropin, is a protein that promotes the growth of specific types of cells, making it particularly important during early development. It is perhaps best known for its effect on the overall increase in height during childhood and adolescence. However, adults also produce GH; it is associated with general health and energy level as well as cognitive function. GH secretion is regulated by the hypothalamic peptide hormones (GHRH) and (GHIH), also known as somatostatin.

pageData.text: Hypersecretion (excessive secretion) or hyposecretion (undersecretion) of GH may have marked effects on growth. Hypersecretion may result from a tumor of the anterior pituitary or hypothalamus. Hypersecretion in childhood can lead to , which is extremely rapid growth to a great height, sometimes exceeding eight feet. Hypersecretion in adults causes a similar condition called . In acromegaly, bones increase in size but the body does not increase its overall height. The hands, feet, and face in particular become enlarged. Hyposecretion during childhood can cause , presenting as slow growth and an unusually short stature. Pituitary dwarfism is usually genetic in origin but may also result from trauma to the anterior pituitary and/or hypothalamus.

text: (PRL) is an anterior pituitary protein hormone that stimulates milk production by the mammary glands. Its secretion is stimulated by (TRH), a hypothalamic peptide that also targets the . Prolactin secretion is inhibited by the hypothalamic amine (PIH), also known as dopamine. Dopamine is a —a chemical messenger used by the nervous system.
(TSH), or thyrotropin, is an protein that targets the . TSH secretion is stimulated by the hypothalamic peptide TRH and inhibited by as well as the hypothalamic hormone GHIH.

(ACTH), or corticotropin, is an anterior pituitary peptide that targets the outer layer, or cortex, of the . Its secretion is triggered by the hypothalamic peptide (CRH). Both of these hormones play important roles in the stress response.

(LH) and (FSH) are anterior pituitary peptides known together as the because they target the gonads (ovaries and testes). Their release is triggered by the hypothalamic peptide (GnRH). Hormones produced by the gonads inhibit LH and FSH secretion. In both men and women, FSH promotes gamete production and LH stimulates the production of sex hormones by the gonads.

(MSH) is a peptide that targets skin cells called melanocytes because they produce the pigment melanin. Melanocytes are able to respond on their own to ultraviolet light exposure, causing the skin to darken. However, hormone fluctuations can also cause the skin to darken. For example, MSH levels rise during pregnancy and contribute to increased skin pigmentation at that time. MSH is of greater importance in certain nonhuman vertebrates. For example, frogs and toads adjust the darkness of their skin according to the light levels of their surroundings to make themselves less visible to predators and prey.

pageData.subTitle: Thyroid and Parathyroid Glands
pageData.text: The is a butterfly-shaped endocrine gland located in the anterior neck, just inferior to the larynx, or Adam’s apple (see ). Its main secretion, commonly referred to as (TH), is actually two structurally similar, iodine-containing amines: and . TH targets most cells of the body, affecting metabolism and body temperature; cardiovascular and respiratory function; and growth and development, especially of the brain. As previously mentioned, TH secretion is stimulated by TSH from the and TRH from the . Rising blood levels of TH suppress the secretion of TSH and TRH.

Hyposecretion of TH can occur for a variety of reasons, including a thyroid injury or removal, lack of adequate TSH and/or TRH, or a dietary iodine deficiency. Severe hypothyroidism is known as <button class='glossary-text'>myxedema</button>. The skin becomes thick and dry, and the face looks puffy. The individual feels cold and lethargic; gains weight; has a slow pulse and a hoarse, slurred voice; and experiences constipation. If untreated, the individual may fall into a coma and can even die. If myxedema is caused by dietary iodine deficiency, the individual may develop a swollen thyroid, called a <button class='glossary-text'>goiter</button>. In the absence of iodine, the thyroid attempts to produce TH but instead only produces a precursor, thyroglobin, which builds up and causes the gland to swell.

The most common form of hyperthyroidism is <button class='glossary-text'>Graves’ disease</button>. This is an autoimmune disorder in which the immune system attacks the thyroid gland. However, instead of destroying the thyroid, the immune attack acts as TSH, thereby causing TH hypersecretion. Individuals with Graves’ disease may feel anxious and irritable; have an elevated heart rate; feel fatigued; and experience weight loss, frequent bowel movements, heat intolerance, moist skin, and increased sweating. In untreated Graves’ disease, the eyes may protrude, a condition called <button class='glossary-text'>exophthalmos</button>.

The thyroid also secretes , a peptide that helps reduce blood calcium (Ca2+) levels (see Figure 5). Calcitonin targets the skeleton as well as the intestine and kidneys. Calcitonin’s effect is often described as “bone-sparing” because it inhibits the activity of osteoclasts—bone cells that break down bone tissue and release Ca2+ into the bloodstream. Calcitonin also promotes the deposition of Ca2+ into bone tissue. In the kidneys, this inhibits the reabsorption of Ca2+, so it is excreted in the urine. Ca2+ absorption in the small intestine is inhibited by calcitonin. However, calcitonin’s role in Ca2+ regulation in humans is relatively minor, and an individual who must have the removed does not usually require supplemental calcitonin.

The are small glands embedded in the posterior surface of the thyroid. There are typically four of them, although the number can vary between individuals. These glands secrete (PTH), or parathormone, a protein that has an action opposite to and much more powerful than that of calcitonin (see Figure 5). PTH secretion is stimulated by low blood Ca2+ and serves to increase blood Ca2+ levels. PTH facilitates the release of Ca2+ from the skeleton into the bloodstream and inhibits Ca2+ reabsorption in the kidneys. PTH also promotes Ca2+ absorption in the small intestine. Vitamin D is necessary for intestinal Ca2+ absorption; however, it must first be converted to its active form. This step occurs in the kidneys under the influence of PTH. PTH secretion is inhibited by rising levels of Ca2+ in the blood. Loss of the parathyroids can have devastating effects and can often be fatal. PTH deficit, or , results in very low blood Ca2+. The nervous system requires adequate Ca2+ for normal function. As the condition worsens, an individual may experience tingling sensations; increasingly severe muscle cramps; and if untreated, convulsions, respiratory paralysis, and even death.

pageData.altText: Figure 5: Diagram depicting the effects of calcitonin and parathyroid hormone on blood calcium level

pageData.question: PTH facilitates the release of_________from the skeleton into the bloodstream.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: PTH facilitates the release of calcium (Ca<sup class='bodySupscript'>2+</sup>) from the skeleton into the bloodstream and inhibits Ca<sup class='bodySupscript'>2+</sup> reabsorption in the kidneys. PTH also promotes Ca2+ absorption in the small intestine.

pageData.question: Which of the following does the thyroid secrete to help reduce blood calcium levels?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The thyroid secretes calcitonin, a peptide that helps reduce blood calcium (Ca<sup class='bodySupscript'>2+</sup>) levels.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Parathyroid hormone (PTH), or parathormone, a protein that has an action opposite to and much more powerful than that of calcitonin. PTH helps maintain an appropriate balance of calcium in the bloodstream and in tissues that depend on calcium for proper functioning.

img.alt: Figure 5: Diagram depicting the effects of calcitonin and parathyroid hormone on blood calcium level

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Parathyroid hormone (PTH), or parathormone, a protein that has an action opposite to and much more powerful than that of calcitonin. PTH helps maintain an appropriate balance of calcium in the bloodstream and in tissues that depend on calcium for proper functioning.

img.alt: Figure 5: Diagram depicting the effects of calcitonin and parathyroid hormone on blood calcium level

pageData.subTitle: Adrenal Glands
pageData.text: There are two , or suprarenal glands, positioned so one is atop each kidney. An adrenal gland has two layers, each with endocrine functions.The outer layer of an adrenal gland, which makes up the bulk of the gland, is the . It secretes three types of . Two of them, the and , are often referred to together as the . The third type, the , are so named because they are also produced by the gonads.

text: Mineralocorticoids are important for regulating the electrolyte-fluid balance of the body. The main mineralocorticoid is <button class='glossary-text'>aldosterone</button>, which targets the kidneys, promoting the absorption of sodium (Na+) and water, along with the secretion of potassium (K+). Aldosterone secretion is stimulated by the peptide <button class='glossary-text'>hormone</button> angiotensin, the precursor of which is produced by the liver; elevated blood K+; and, to a lesser extent, by ACTH.

pageData.text: Hypersecretion of aldosterone is known as (or simply aldosteronism) and can be caused by an adrenal cortex tumor. Due to excessive Na+ in the body and water retention, blood pressure is elevated. Edema (swelling) is common., or hypoaldosteronism, results in elevated blood K+ (hyperkalemia). The consequences range from muscle pain and weakness, an irregular heart rate, and/or numbness to a potentially fatal cardiac arrest. Aldosterone hyposecretion may also occur in , a disorder in which not enough corticosteroids are produced.

text: Glucocorticoids are so named because of their effects on glucose (blood sugar) metabolism. They also affect the immune system and play an important role in suppressing inflammation. The primary glucocorticoid is <button class='glossary-text'>cortisol</button>, which is a vital part of the body’s stress response. (Cortisol may also be prescribed as the anti-inflammatory medication hydrocortisone.)

pageData.text: When the body is under stress—a disruption to homeostasis—both the nervous and endocrine systems are activated. There is a short-term response to an immediate stressor, often described as the fight-or-flight response, and a more long-term response. The main components of the involved in the long-term stress response are the hypothal-amus, , and , which together form the (see Figure 6).

Stimulated by a stressor, the <button class='glossary-text'>hypothalamus</button> secretes CRH, which causes the anterior pituitary to release ACTH. The adrenal cortex secretes <button class='glossary-text'>glucocorticoids</button> (mainly <button class='glossary-text'>cortisol</button>). Most cells in the body are target cells for glucocorticoids, so rising levels of these <button class='glossary-text'>hormones</button> bring about widespread changes in the body, including alterations in glucose metabolism and the immune response. Cortisol causes blood glucose to increase, which supplies ready energy for the body. At the same time, cortisol helps keep the immune response, particularly inflammation, in check.
As cortisol levels rise, this hormone acts on the hypothalamus and pituitary to reduce CRH and ACTH secretion.

pageData.altText: Figure 6: Diagram depicting the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis

pageData.text: If levels of become chronically too high, hypercortisolism, or , can result. This can be caused by corticosteroid medication or by tumors of components of the HPA axis that result in hypersecretion of . People with Cushing’s syndrome have a distinctive pattern of weight gain in the abdomen and upper back, especially as a “buffalo hump” between the shoulders. Weight gain in the face gives the individual a rounded “moon face” appearance. The skin is also affected, becoming thin, slow to heal, and acne-prone; stretch marks are common due to rapid weight gain. Infertility, fatigue, cognitive decline, depression, irritability, and anxiety may also occur. Because the inflammatory response is suppressed, infections tend to become very serious before they are recognized, which makes them much more difficult to treat.

Glucocorticoid hyposecretion can result in <button class='glossary-text'>Addison’s disease</button>. People with this condition may experience weight loss, anorexia (reduced appetite), nausea, diarrhea and vomiting, fatigue, muscle and joint pain, low blood pressure, low blood glucose, salt craving, irritability, and depression. The bones tend to become weak and prone to fractures.

text: are so named due to their effects on the gonads. The main gonadocorticoids are . These are steroids (or steroid precursors) that are converted to testosterone or estrogen after secretion. The effects of gonadocorticoids on males are slight, since most of their androgens—primarily testosterone—are produced by the testes. However, adrenal androgens are quite important in females. They are responsible for the growth of pubic and axillary hair in puberty, contribute to the sex drive, and are converted to estrogen in post-menopausal women.Hypersecretion of gonadocorticoids usually has a greater impact in females than males, especially if it occurs early in development. is a general hypersecretion from the that can result from various genetic disorders. The results of this condition can range from ambiguous genitalia in infants to abnormal puberty, excessive facial hair, and irregular menstruation and infertility. Hyposecretion is generally less problematic than hypersecretion.

pageData.text: The inner layer of an <button class='glossary-text'>adrenal gland</button> is the <button class='glossary-text'>adrenal medulla</button>. It functions as part of the nervous system as well as the <button class='glossary-text'>endocrine system</button>, and secretion of its amine <button class='glossary-text'>hormones</button>, known as the <button class='glossary-text'>catecholamines</button>, is stimulated by input from the nervous system. The adrenal catecholamines—<button class='glossary-text'>epinephrine (adrenaline)</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>norepinephrine (noradrenaline)</button>—are both derived from the same amino acid (tyrosine). In addition to their role as hormones, they also modulate activity in the central nervous system. They are faster-acting than typical hormones and, along with the nervous system, are key players in the short-term stress response. This response involves increased heart rate and blood pressure, dilation of the bronchioles, increased blood glucose and overall metabolic rate, reduction of blood flow to the gastrointestinal tract, and elevated urine output. If catecholamine levels remain too high, the fight-or-flight response is maintained. Sustained elevated blood pressure can be particularly harmful to the body.

pageData.subTitle: Pancreas
pageData.text: The is a fish-shaped organ located in the abdominal cavity, just behind the stomach (see ). It has an exocrine gland function as part of the digestive system, secreting pancreatic juice into the first segment of the small intestine. It is also an important , secreting a number of into the bloodstream. Two of them, the protein and the peptide , are particularly important in regulating blood glucose (see Figure 7) and, therefore, energy homeostasis in the body. Blood glucose levels naturally rise after a meal and fall as the glucose is used or stored.

text: Insulin reduces blood glucose levels by stimulating its target cells to take in glucose. Insulin has widespread effects, because most cells of the body have insulin receptors. Insulin secretion is triggered mainly by rising blood glucose, although other hormones, including the <button class='glossary-text'>glucocorticoids</button>, also exert an influence. Insulin causes excess glucose to be converted to glycogen for storage in the liver and inhibits the breakdown of glycogen to glucose. Insulin secretion normally declines as blood glucose begins to fall.

pageData.altText: Figure 7: Diagram depicting the effects of insulin and glucagon on blood glucose levels

pageData.question: Which of the following responses is most likely to occur after eating?

options.text: The pancreas secretes insulin to trigger glucose uptake by the liver.
The liver breaks down glycogen into glucose monomers.
The liver secretes glucagon to trigger glucose uptake by the pancreas.
Glucagon binds to glucose to synthesize glycogen polymers.
Red blood cells secrete insulin to trigger glucose uptake by other cells.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The pancreas detects elevated blood glucose levels and secretes insulin in response. Insulin has several targets, including the liver which takes up glucose and stores it as glycogen.

pageData.question: Glucagon levels in the blood are likely to be higher under which of the following circumstances?

options.text: after blood glucose levels drop below the normal range
when blood glucose levels are elevated
after insulin signals the liver to take up glucose

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Glucagon is produced by the pancreas in response to a drop in blood glucose levels.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Blood glucose levels naturally rise after a meal. Insulin reduces blood glucose levels by stimulating its target cells to take in glucose. Glucagon, on the other hand, functions to elevate blood glucose. It targets mainly the liver, causing the break-down of glycogen and release of glucose into the bloodstream and the synthesis of glucose from noncarbohydrate molecules. The main stimulus for glucagon secretion is falling blood glucose.

img.alt: Figure 7: Diagram depicting the effects of insulin and glucagon on blood glucose levels

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Blood glucose levels naturally rise after a meal. Insulin reduces blood glucose levels by stimulating its target cells to take in glucose. Glucagon, on the other hand, functions to elevate blood glucose. It targets mainly the liver, causing the break-down of glycogen and release of glucose into the bloodstream and the synthesis of glucose from noncarbohydrate molecules. The main stimulus for glucagon secretion is falling blood glucose.

img.alt: Figure 7: Diagram depicting the effects of insulin and glucagon on blood glucose levels

pageData.text: Some individuals lack proper <button class='glossary-text'>insulin</button> activity, and as a result, their blood glucose levels can go very high—a state called <button class='glossary-text'>hyperglycemia</button>—while their body cells are starved for fuel. This condition is known as <button class='glossary-text'>diabetes mellitus</button>. It is characterized by <button class='glossary-text'>polyuria</button>; <button class='glossary-text'>polydipsia</button>; and intense hunger, or <button class='glossary-text'>polyphagia</button>. Other indicators are unexplained weight loss, vision changes, fatigue, susceptibility to infections, dry skin, wounds that are slow to heal, and numbness and/or tingling in the hands or feet. Ketones—fatty acid metabolites formed when fats are broken down for energy—may accumulate in the bloodstream, causing blood pH to drop, a condition called <button class='glossary-text'>ketoacidosis</button>. Complications of diabetes mellitus can include permanent damage to organs, including the heart and blood vessels, kidneys, nerves, and eyes.

There are two types of diabetes mellitus. <button class='glossary-text'>Type 1 diabetes</button> results from insulin hyposecretion. Although this condition tends to arise more commonly in children and adolescents, it can also develop in adults. The precise cause is unknown, but genetic predisposition and viral infection may lead to the characteristic lack of functional insulin-secreting cells. Type I diabetes is treatable with insulin as well as careful attention to diet. <button class='glossary-text'>Type 2 diabetes</button> results from insulin hypoactivity. In other words, target cells are not sensitive to insulin and cannot respond to it. This is known as <button class='glossary-text'>insulin resistance</button>. The problem seems to lie with the insulin receptors and/or their signal transduction mechanism. Treatment includes diet and lifestyle changes, medications that combat insulin resistance, and insulin if necessary. Although type 2 diabetes occurs more commonly in adults, it can also occur in children.

Hypersecretion of insulin, or <button class='glossary-text'>hyperinsulinism</button>, drives blood glucose levels down, a state known as <button class='glossary-text'>hypoglycemia</button>. In this state, the person feels weak, shaky, and disoriented. Sometimes hyperinsulinism is caused by a pancreatic tumor, but it can also occur in individuals with diabetes who accidentally overdose with insulin.

text: <button class='glossary-text'>Glucagon</button> functions to elevate blood glucose. It targets mainly the liver, causing the breakdown of glycogen and release of glucose into the bloodstream and the synthesis of glucose from noncarbohydrate molecules. The main stimulus for glucagon secretion is falling blood glucose. Its suppressors include rising blood glucose and <button class='glossary-text'>insulin</button>. Glucagon can be administered medically by injection to treat someone with severe <button class='glossary-text'>hypoglycemia</button>. Hypersecretion may occur due to a tumor of the <button class='glossary-text'>pancreas</button>. The resulting <button class='glossary-text'>hyperglycemia</button> may lead to ketoacidosis if untreated. Hyposecretion is rare; if the pancreas must be surgically removed, then the individual loses the ability to produce insulin as well as glucagon. Blood glucose levels must be monitored carefully and maintained by the administration of insulin.

pageData.subTitle: Pineal Gland
pageData.text: The is located posterior to the (see ). It is named for its distinctive shape, which resembles a pinecone. Its main secretion is the amine , which is released in a daily cycle. The pineal gland is able to respond to changes in light levels because it receives indirect input from the visual pathways that link the retinas of the eyes with other regions of the brain. Melatonin release is normally highest at night and lowest around midday. It plays an important role in the sleep-wake cycle, inducing drowsiness when it is time to sleep. Melatonin levels are higher in children and lower in adults. It is thought that melatonin may help delay the onset of puberty.

pageData.subTitle: Thymus
pageData.text: The is located inferior to the and anterior to the heart (see ). It belongs to the lymphatic and immune system as well as the . The primary endocrine function of the thymus is to support development of the immune system. It is large and prominent in infants and young children but begins to shrink with adolescence. The thymus in elderly individuals consists mainly of fatty tissue. Interestingly, its secretions—including the peptide —act mainly on the thymus itself.

pageData.subTitle: Gonads and Placenta
pageData.text: The gonads and placenta belong to the reproductive system as well as the endocrine system. The gonads produce sex cells (eggs and sperm), and the placenta is a temporary organ of pregnancy.

The female gonads, or ovaries, are located in the abdominopelvic cavity (see Figure 3). They produce estrogens and progesterone. (Estrogens were discussed with the .) Progesterone assists estrogens in breast development and regulation of the menstrual cycle. Progesterone is important for maintaining the lining of the uterus during pregnancy.

The male gonads, or testes, are in a pouch located outside the abdominopelvic cavity called the scrotum (see Figure 3). Their main hormonal secretion is testosterone, the same as that produced by the adrenal cortex.

The placenta supports the developing fetus during pregnancy while also secreting hormones. These include estrogens and progesterone as well as the protein (hCG)—the hormone detected by many pregnancy tests. hCG is produced after embryonic implantation and helps maintain ovarian progesterone production during pregnancy.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which hormone is released from the posterior lobe of the pituitary gland?
Which hormone is important in maintaining the body's circadian rhythm?
Which of the following hormones is NOT produced by the adrenal cortex?
Which of the following hormones serve(s) to increase blood glucose levels?
Which hormone stimulates the maturation of T-lymphocytes, which are essential cells of the immune system?
Which hormone is produced by the small intestine?
Which hormone stimulates egg maturation in females, and testosterone production in males?
Which hormone stimulates water reabsorption in kidneys?
Which of the following nutrients does the thyroid require to synthesize hormones?
Which hormone increases calcium levels in the blood?

You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read the background carefully before you begin working so you are prepared for the case studies provided by your instructor for Activity 1.

title: Table 1.
Major Endocrine Glands and Their Hormones

pageData.text: There are 10 case studies provided in the Lab Notebook. Your instructor will assign certain of these case studies for you to read and evaluate.

For this activity, your instructor will assign case studies for you to complete. Each case study includes a brief scenario describing a patient with an endocrine-related health condition. The scenario may involve signs and/or symptoms.

text: Signs are objective evidence of an individual’s health state that may be observed by someone else, such as a health-care provider.
Symptoms are subjective experiences of one’s own state of health.

pageData.text: For example, an individual with a bacterial infection may have a temperature of 101˚ F. This is a sign that can be observed and measured using a thermometer. The feverish individual may feel tired and irritable and have chills and a headache. These are symptoms that may be described to a health-care provider but are only experienced subjectively. Signs may include the results of medical examinations and tests. Consult <button class='resource-text'>Table 2</button> for reference ranges for selected laboratory tests, as defined by the American Board of Internal Medicine. Your instructor may direct you to additional resources. Use the information provided to answer a series of questions about each case and closely related aspects of endocrine structure and function.

pageData.text: A male patient enters your office. He is in his mid-30s and in decent physical shape. He complains about being tired and seems to be gaining some weight, while not eating more than normal. He also describes being cold all the time. You decide to perform a blood test and receive the following results.
After reviewing his results, you come to a conclusion. What might be wrong with this patient and how does this diagnosis correlate with the symptoms presented by the patient?

A 46-year-old female patient checks into the office. She has broken bones several times over the last couple of months, yet she maintains a lifestyle which does not include strenuous activities that could lead to these types of injuries. You perform some blood tests and receive the following results.
After reviewing her results, you come to a conclusion. What might be wrong with this patient and how does this diagnosis correlate with the symptoms presented by the patient?

A 24-year-old female patient enters the office. She has low blood glucose levels. A urine test also indicates very low levels of minerals in her urine. She has an infrequent and light menstrual period. You perform a blood test and receive the following results.
After reviewing her results, you come to a conclusion. What might be wrong with this patient and how does this diagnosis correlate with the symptoms presented by the patient?

A 42-year-old male patient checks into the office. He presents with slow tissue regeneration after receiving a cut, and his bones are slow to mend. He is concerned and thinks that his relocation to North Carolina might be a contributing factor. You perform a blood test and receive the following results.
After reviewing his results, you come to a conclusion. What might be wrong with this patient and how does this diagnosis correlate with the symptoms presented by the patient?

A 38-year-old male patient enters the office complaining about muscle twitches and feeling on edge. His pupils are dilated, and he notes an increase in body temperature. What hormone could be outside normal values and why?

A 12-year-old boy notices several changes occurring in his body. Hair is starting to grow in places it did not grow before, his voice is changing, and he has recently undergone several growth spurts. What is the most likely explanation for these symptoms and which hormone is involved?
After eating cotton candy at a fair, which hormone will increase and why?

A patient notices an increase in fluid loss and a general feeling of unease. After performing a blood test, you note that the patient has low fluid volume and low levels of electrolytes. Which hormone might be responsible for these symptoms?

A 48-year-old female patient enters the office and complains about being unable to sleep at night, while starting to fall asleep right at daybreak. Which hormone might be responsible for these symptoms?

A 14-year-old female patient enters the office and complains about frequent urination. She is also thirsty and has some sleep issues. These symptoms make her feel nervous and on edge. Blood glucose level in this patient is normal. Which hormone might be involved and why?

data.title: Acromegaly
data.content: Abnormal growth of the hands, feet, and face, caused by overproduction of growth hormone (GH)

data.title: Addison’s disease
data.content: A disorder in which not enough corticosteroids are produced

data.title: Adrenal cortex
data.content: Outer layer of an adrenal gland

data.title: Adrenal gland (suprarenal gland)
data.content: A small gland that makes steroid hormones

data.title: Adrenal medulla
data.content: The inner layer of an adrenal gland

data.title: Adrenocorticotropic hormone
data.content: An anterior pituitary peptide that targets the outer layer (cortex) of the adrenal glands; abbreviated ACTH; also called corticotropin

data.title: Aldosterone
data.content: Hormone that regulate the production of other hormones targets the kidneys, promoting the absorption of sodium and water, along with the secretion of potassium

data.title: Aldosterone hyposecretion
data.content: A condition which results in elevated blood potassium (hyperkalemia); also called hypoaldosteronism

data.title: Androgens
data.content: Steroids (or steroid precursors) that are converted to testosterone or estrogen after secretion

data.title: Anterior pituitary
data.content: One of the two lobes of the pituitary gland, and which synthesizes and secretes a number of hormones

data.title: Antidiuretic hormone
data.content: A peptide that promotes the formation of concentrated urine by the kidneys; abbreviated ADH; also called vasopressin

data.title: Calcitonin
data.content: A peptide that helps reduce blood calcium levels

data.title: Catecholamines
data.content: Amine hormones secreted by the adrenal gland

data.title: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia
data.content: A general hypersecretion from the adrenal cortex that can result from various genetic disorders, sympotoms can range from ambiguous genitalia in infants to abnormal puberty, excessive facial hair, and irregular menstruation and infertility

data.title: Corticosteroids
data.content: A group of steroid hormones produced in the adrenal cortex

data.title: Corticotropin-releasing hormone
data.content: A peptide hormone that activates the synthesis and release of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) from the pituitary gland; abbreviated CRH

data.title: Cortisol
data.content: A stress hormone

data.title: Cushing’s syndrome
data.content: The disorder caused by the body's exposure to an excess amount of cortisol

data.title: Diabetes insipidus
data.content: Disease in which the kidneys are unable to concentrate urine due to either an antidiuretic hormone (ADH) deficiency or the kidneys’ inability to respond to the hormone

data.title: Diabetes mellitus
data.content: A group of diseases that affect how the body uses blood sugar

data.title: Endocrine gland
data.content: A gland that secretes hormones into the bloodstream

data.title: Endocrine system
data.content: A collection of glands, including the pituitary, thyroid, and pancreas, that produces hormones that are released directly into the blood

data.title: Epinephrine (adrenaline)
data.content: A hormone secreted by the adrenal medulla, stimulated by the central nervous system in response to stress, as anger or fear

data.title: Exophthalmos
data.content: The condition of bulging or protruding eyeballs

data.title: First messenger
data.content: A nonsteroid hormone that binds to cell-surface receptors

data.title: Follicle-stimulating hormone
data.content: Anterior pituitary peptide that target the gonads; abbreviated FSH

data.title: Gigantism
data.content: Abnormally large growth due to an excess of growth hormone (GH) during childhood

data.title: Glucagon
data.content: A peptide made in the pancreas that regulates blood glucose

data.title: Glucocorticoids
data.content: A class of corticosteroids, steroid hormones

data.title: Goiter
data.content: A swollen thyroid

data.title: Gonadocorticoid
data.content: Group of steroids secreted by the adrenal cortex

data.title: Gonadotropin-releasing hormone
data.content: A hormone that causes the pituitary gland in the brain to make and secrete luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH); abbreviated GnRH

data.title: Gonadotropins
data.content: A collective term for luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)

data.title: Graves’ disease
data.content: An autoimmune disorder in which the immune system attacks the thyroid gland

data.title: Growth hormone
data.content: A protein that promotes the growth of specific types of cells, making it particularly important during early development; abbreviated GH; also called somatotropin

data.title: Growth hormone inhibiting hormone
data.content: A hormone that inhibits the secretion of several  hormones; abbreviated GHIH; also called somatostatin

data.title: Growth hormone-releasing hormone
data.content: Hypothalamic peptide hormone that regulates growth hormone (GH) secretion; abbreviated GHRH

data.title: Hormone
data.content: Signaling molecules in the body

data.title: Human chorionic gonadotropin
data.content: The hormone detected by many pregnancy tests as it is produced after embryonic implantation; abbreviated hCG

data.title: Hyperaldosteronism
data.content: Hypersecretion of aldosterone is known as hyperaldosteronism (or simply aldosteronism) and can be caused by an adrenal cortex tumor

data.title: Hyperglycemia
data.content: A condition in which there is an excess of glucose in the bloodstream; often associated with diabetes mellitus

data.title: Hyperinsulinism
data.content: A condition in which too much insulin is released, causing blood glucose levels to drop

data.title: Hypoglycemia
data.content: A condition in which there is there are low blood glucose levels causing a person to feel weak, shaky, and disoriented

data.title: Hypoparathyroidism
data.content: A condition in which one or more of the parathyroid glands does not make enough parathyroid hormone (PTH)

data.title: Hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis
data.content: A term used to represent the interaction between the hypothalamus, pituitary gland, and adrenal glands; abbreviated HPA axis

data.title: Hypothalamus
data.content: The area of the brain that produces hormones

data.title: Insulin
data.content: A hormone produced in the pancreas that regulates the amount of glucose in the blood

data.title: Insulin resistance
data.content: Target cells can not respond to insulin

data.title: Ketoacidosis
data.content: The accumulation of fatty acid metabolites in the bloodstream causing blood pH to drop

data.title: Luteinizing hormone
data.content: The anterior pituitary peptide that targets the gonads; abbreviated LH

data.title: Melanocyte-stimulating hormone
data.content: A peptide that targets skin cells called melanocytes; abbreviated MSH

data.title: Melatonin
data.content: The hormone that regulates the body's sleep-wake cycle

data.title: Mineralocorticoids
data.content: Hormones that are important for regulating the electrolyte-fluid balance of the body

data.title: Myxedema
data.content: Swelling of the skin and underlying tissues, often caused by an underactive thyroid gland

data.title: Negative feedback
data.content: Stabilizing feedback; for example, a signal sent to a gland reduces or stops secretion of a hormone

data.title: Neurotransmitter
data.content: A chemical messenger used by the nervous system

data.title: Nonsteroid hormone
data.content: Water-soluble proteins, peptides, or amino acids

data.title: Norepinephrine (noradrenaline)
data.content: Acts as a hormone and a chemical messenger used by nerve cells

data.title: Oxytocin
data.content: A peptide hormone that effects the release of milk from the mammary glands (the letdown reflex), and also brings about cervical dilation and uterine contractions during labor

data.title: Pancreas
data.content: Fish-shaped organ located in the abdominal cavity

data.title: Parathyroid glands
data.content: Small glands embedded in the posterior surface of the thyroid

data.title: Parathyroid hormone
data.content: Protein that has an action opposite to and much more powerful than that of calcitonin; abbreviated PTH; also called parathormone

data.title: Pineal gland
data.content: Located posterior to the hypothalamus; resembles a pinecone in shape

data.title: Pituitary dwarfism
data.content: Condition caused by insufficient amounts of growth hormone (GH)

data.title: Pituitary gland
data.content: A pea-sized gland attached to the base of the brain that produces hormones, especially those associated with growth and development

data.title: Polydipsia
data.content: Intense thirst that is not relieved by fluid intake

data.title: Polyphagia
data.content: Intense hunger

data.title: Polyuria
data.content: Production of a large volume of dilute urine

data.title: Positive feedback
data.content: Amplification of the response to a stimulus that is disruptive to homeostasis; for example, a signal increases secretion of a hormone

data.title: Posterior pituitary
data.content: One of the two lobes of the pituitary glandthat secretes hormones synthesized by the hypothalamus

data.title: Prolactin
data.content: An anterior pituitary protein hormone that stimulates milk production by the mammary glands; abbreviated PRL

data.title: Prolactin-inhibiting hormone
data.content: A neurotransmitter; abbreviated PIH; also called dopamine

data.title: Second messenger
data.content: A molecule whose release within a cell is promoted by a hormone

data.title: Steroid hormone
data.content: Small lipid molecules synthesized from cholesterol

data.title: Thymosin
data.content: A peptide secreted by, and which acts on, the thymus

data.title: Thymus
data.content: An organ that belongs to the lymphatic, immune, and endocrine systems; located inferior to the thyroid gland and anterior to the heart

data.title: Thyroid gland
data.content: A butterfly-shaped endocrine gland located in the anterior neck

data.title: Thyroid hormone
data.content: Refers to two structurally similar iodine-containing amines: thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3); abbreviated TH

data.title: Thyroid-stimulating hormone
data.content: An anterior pituitary protein that targets the thyroid gland; abbreviated TSH; also called thyrotropin

data.title: Thyrotropin-releasing hormone
data.content: A hypothalamic peptide that targets the thyroid gland; abbreviated TRH

data.title: Thyroxine (T4)
data.content: The main hormone produced by the thyroid gland

data.title: Triiodothyronine (T3)
data.content: One of two major hormones made by your thyroid, affects almost every physiological process in the body

data.title: Tropic hormone
data.content: A hormone that regulates the production of other hormones

data.title: Type 1 diabetes
data.content: A chronic condition, pancreas produces little or no insulin

data.title: Type 2 diabetes
data.content: A chronic condition that impacts the way the body uses glucose
